trans-unit.source: Plan your user and device groups | Microsoft Intune
trans-unit.target: Plan your user and device groups | Microsoft Intune

trans-unit.source: Plan groups to meet your organizational needs.
trans-unit.target: Plan groups to meet your organizational needs.

trans-unit.source: Plan your user and device groups
trans-unit.target: Plan your user and device groups

trans-unit.source: Groups in Intune give you great flexibility when you're managing your devices and users.
trans-unit.target: Groups in Intune give you great flexibility when you're managing your devices and users.

trans-unit.source: You can set up groups to suit your organizational needs according to:
trans-unit.target: You can set up groups to suit your organizational needs according to:

trans-unit.source: geographic location
trans-unit.target: geographic location

trans-unit.source: department
trans-unit.target: department

trans-unit.source: hardware characteristics
trans-unit.target: hardware characteristics

trans-unit.source: operating system
trans-unit.target: operating system

trans-unit.source: whether the device is user-owned or company-owned
trans-unit.target: whether the device is user-owned or company-owned

trans-unit.source: How Intune groups work
trans-unit.target: How Intune groups work

trans-unit.source: This is the default view of the **Groups** node in the Intune admin console:
trans-unit.target: This is the default view of the **Groups** node in the Intune admin console:

trans-unit.source: Screenshot of the default view of the Groups node in the Intune console
trans-unit.target: Screenshot of the default view of the Groups node in the Intune console

trans-unit.source: Policies are deployed to groups, so group hierarchy is one of your key design considerations.
trans-unit.target: Policies are deployed to groups, so group hierarchy is one of your key design considerations.

trans-unit.source: It's important to know that you cannot change a group’s parent group after you've created the group.
trans-unit.target: It's important to know that you cannot change a group’s parent group after you've created the group.

trans-unit.source: How you design your groups is critically important from the moment you start using the Intune service.
trans-unit.target: How you design your groups is critically important from the moment you start using the Intune service.

trans-unit.source: Some recommended practices for designing a group hierarchy based on your organizational needs are described here.
trans-unit.target: Some recommended practices for designing a group hierarchy based on your organizational needs are described here.

trans-unit.source: Group membership rules
trans-unit.target: Group membership rules

trans-unit.source: A group can contain either users or devices, but not both.
trans-unit.target: A group can contain either users or devices, but not both.

trans-unit.source: **Device groups**.
trans-unit.target: **Device groups**.

trans-unit.source: This includes computers and mobile devices.
trans-unit.target: This includes computers and mobile devices.

trans-unit.source: Before you can add a computer to a group, it must be enrolled.
trans-unit.target: Before you can add a computer to a group, it must be enrolled.

trans-unit.source: Before you can add a mobile device to a group, your environment must be configured to support mobile devices, and the device must be enrolled or discovered in Exchange ActiveSync.
trans-unit.target: Before you can add a mobile device to a group, your environment must be configured to support mobile devices, and the device must be enrolled or discovered in Exchange ActiveSync.

trans-unit.source: **User groups**.
trans-unit.target: **User groups**.

trans-unit.source: A group can have users from security groups.
trans-unit.target: A group can have users from security groups.

trans-unit.source: Security groups sync with your instance of Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Security groups sync with your instance of Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: If you do not sync with Active Directory, you can manually create these groups.
trans-unit.target: If you do not sync with Active Directory, you can manually create these groups.

trans-unit.source: A device or a user can belong to more than one group.
trans-unit.target: A device or a user can belong to more than one group.

trans-unit.source: A group can include and exclude members based on the following membership rules:
trans-unit.target: A group can include and exclude members based on the following membership rules:

trans-unit.source: **Criteria Membership**.
trans-unit.target: **Criteria Membership**.

trans-unit.source: These are dynamic rules that Intune runs to include or exclude members.
trans-unit.target: These are dynamic rules that Intune runs to include or exclude members.

trans-unit.source: These criteria use security groups and other information synced with your local instance of Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: These criteria use security groups and other information synced with your local instance of Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: When the security group or data changes, the group membership changes when you sync with Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: When the security group or data changes, the group membership changes when you sync with Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: **Direct Membership**.
trans-unit.target: **Direct Membership**.

trans-unit.source: These are static rules that explicitly add or exclude members.
trans-unit.target: These are static rules that explicitly add or exclude members.

trans-unit.source: The membership list is static.
trans-unit.target: The membership list is static.

trans-unit.source: Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) is not required when you create user groups or device groups that include users or computers.
trans-unit.target: Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) is not required when you create user groups or device groups that include users or computers.

trans-unit.source: But, for device groups to include mobile devices, your environment must be configured to support mobile devices.
trans-unit.target: But, for device groups to include mobile devices, your environment must be configured to support mobile devices.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, the devices must be discovered and added to Intune.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, the devices must be discovered and added to Intune.

trans-unit.source: Group relationship rules
trans-unit.target: Group relationship rules

trans-unit.source: Each group you create must have a parent group.
trans-unit.target: Each group you create must have a parent group.

trans-unit.source: You cannot change a group’s parent group after you've created the group.
trans-unit.target: You cannot change a group’s parent group after you've created the group.

trans-unit.source: When you add users or devices to a child group:
trans-unit.target: When you add users or devices to a child group:

trans-unit.source: The child group is always a subset of the parent group.
trans-unit.target: The child group is always a subset of the parent group.

trans-unit.source: New members you add to a child group are automatically added to that group’s parent group.
trans-unit.target: New members you add to a child group are automatically added to that group’s parent group.

trans-unit.source: You cannot add a member to a child group when that member is excluded from the parent group.
trans-unit.target: You cannot add a member to a child group when that member is excluded from the parent group.

trans-unit.source: The membership of a parent group defines the available membership for the child group.
trans-unit.target: The membership of a parent group defines the available membership for the child group.

trans-unit.source: When you delete a parent group, all child groups are deleted.
trans-unit.target: When you delete a parent group, all child groups are deleted.

trans-unit.source: You can deploy content and policies to a parent group but exclude the deployment to child groups.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy content and policies to a parent group but exclude the deployment to child groups.

trans-unit.source: You can add a specific user or device to a child group if the user or device is not already a member of the parent group.
trans-unit.target: You can add a specific user or device to a child group if the user or device is not already a member of the parent group.

trans-unit.source: If you do this, the new member of the child group will be added to the parent group.
trans-unit.target: If you do this, the new member of the child group will be added to the parent group.

trans-unit.source: However, you cannot add a member to a child group if the member is excluded from the parent group.
trans-unit.target: However, you cannot add a member to a child group if the member is excluded from the parent group.

trans-unit.source: Group membership is recursive.
trans-unit.target: Group membership is recursive.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: **Pat** is a member of only one group, the **Laptop Users** security group.
trans-unit.target: **Pat** is a member of only one group, the **Laptop Users** security group.

trans-unit.source: The **Laptop Users** group is a member of the **Approved Users** security group.
trans-unit.target: The **Laptop Users** group is a member of the **Approved Users** security group.

trans-unit.source: You create a group in Intune that uses a dynamic membership query that includes the members of the **Approved Users** group.
trans-unit.target: You create a group in Intune that uses a dynamic membership query that includes the members of the **Approved Users** group.

trans-unit.source: The result is that your Intune user group includes **Pat**.
trans-unit.target: The result is that your Intune user group includes **Pat**.

trans-unit.source: When you create groups, think about how you will apply policy.
trans-unit.target: When you create groups, think about how you will apply policy.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might have policies that are specific to device operating systems, or policies that are specific to different roles or organizational units you've already defined in your Active Directory service.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might have policies that are specific to device operating systems, or policies that are specific to different roles or organizational units you've already defined in your Active Directory service.

trans-unit.source: Some admins find it useful to create device groups that are specific to iOS, Android, and Windows.
trans-unit.target: Some admins find it useful to create device groups that are specific to iOS, Android, and Windows.

trans-unit.source: This is in addition to creating user groups for each organizational role.
trans-unit.target: This is in addition to creating user groups for each organizational role.

trans-unit.source: Built-in groups
trans-unit.target: Built-in groups

trans-unit.source: Intune has nine built-in groups that you cannot edit or delete: <!--maybe a screen shot would be best?-->
trans-unit.target: Intune has nine built-in groups that you cannot edit or delete: <!--maybe a screen shot would be best?-->

trans-unit.source: **All Users**
trans-unit.target: **All Users**

trans-unit.source: Ungrouped Users
trans-unit.target: Ungrouped Users

trans-unit.source: **All Devices**
trans-unit.target: **All Devices**

trans-unit.source: All Computers
trans-unit.target: All Computers

trans-unit.source: All Mobile Devices
trans-unit.target: All Mobile Devices

trans-unit.source: All Direct Managed Devices
trans-unit.target: All Direct Managed Devices

trans-unit.source: All Exchange ActiveSync Managed Devices
trans-unit.target: All Exchange ActiveSync Managed Devices

trans-unit.source: All Corporate-owned Devices
trans-unit.target: All Corporate-owned Devices

trans-unit.source: Ungrouped Devices
trans-unit.target: Ungrouped Devices

trans-unit.source: Let your motto be: *keep it simple*.
trans-unit.target: Let your motto be: *keep it simple*.

trans-unit.source: If your organization does not have specific needs like those described in the following sections, keep it simple and go with the default group structure and policies.
trans-unit.target: If your organization does not have specific needs like those described in the following sections, keep it simple and go with the default group structure and policies.

trans-unit.source: This will make the service more manageable in the long term.
trans-unit.target: This will make the service more manageable in the long term.

trans-unit.source: Maintenance will be easier if you can treat your users uniformly.
trans-unit.target: Maintenance will be easier if you can treat your users uniformly.

trans-unit.source: With little differentiation by group, you'll have fewer policies to maintain.
trans-unit.target: With little differentiation by group, you'll have fewer policies to maintain.

trans-unit.source: All users and devices in your organization
trans-unit.target: All users and devices in your organization

trans-unit.source: Define a parent group for all users and devices in your organization.
trans-unit.target: Define a parent group for all users and devices in your organization.

trans-unit.source: You are likely to have policies that will apply to all.
trans-unit.target: You are likely to have policies that will apply to all.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Intune default **All Users** and **All devices** groups for this purpose.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Intune default **All Users** and **All devices** groups for this purpose.

trans-unit.source: Sub-groups that organize devices by specifics, like a group for bring your own device (BYOD) and one for corporate-owned (CO) devices, can be child groups of the **All Users** and **All devices** parent groups.
trans-unit.target: Sub-groups that organize devices by specifics, like a group for bring your own device (BYOD) and one for corporate-owned (CO) devices, can be child groups of the **All Users** and **All devices** parent groups.

trans-unit.source: Customize groups for your organization
trans-unit.target: Customize groups for your organization

trans-unit.source: BYOD and corporate-owned devices
trans-unit.target: BYOD and corporate-owned devices

trans-unit.source: If your organization allows employees to use their own devices, provides company-owned devices, or has a combination of both, we recommend that you apply separate policies for these categories of devices.
trans-unit.target: If your organization allows employees to use their own devices, provides company-owned devices, or has a combination of both, we recommend that you apply separate policies for these categories of devices.

trans-unit.source: In the case of BYOD or a mix, be careful to plan policies that do not infringe on local privacy regulations.
trans-unit.target: In the case of BYOD or a mix, be careful to plan policies that do not infringe on local privacy regulations.

trans-unit.source: Create a parent group for all users who will be bringing their own devices.
trans-unit.target: Create a parent group for all users who will be bringing their own devices.

trans-unit.source: You can use this group to apply policies that are applicable to all users in this category.
trans-unit.target: You can use this group to apply policies that are applicable to all users in this category.

trans-unit.source: Creating a BYOD parent group
trans-unit.target: Creating a BYOD parent group

trans-unit.source: Similarly, you can create a group for the CO device users in your organization:
trans-unit.target: Similarly, you can create a group for the CO device users in your organization:

trans-unit.source: Sibling user groups for BYOD and CO devices
trans-unit.target: Sibling user groups for BYOD and CO devices

trans-unit.source: Groups for geographic regions
trans-unit.target: Groups for geographic regions

trans-unit.source: If your organization needs policies for specific regions, you can create groups based on geographic region.
trans-unit.target: If your organization needs policies for specific regions, you can create groups based on geographic region.

trans-unit.source: You can base them on regional groups that you might have already created in your instance of Active Directory, and sync them with your Azure Active Directory service.
trans-unit.target: You can base them on regional groups that you might have already created in your instance of Active Directory, and sync them with your Azure Active Directory service.

trans-unit.source: You also can create regional groups directly in Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: You also can create regional groups directly in Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: The next screenshots show you how to create Intune groups based on groups synced with your on-premises Active Directory instance.
trans-unit.target: The next screenshots show you how to create Intune groups based on groups synced with your on-premises Active Directory instance.

trans-unit.source: These examples assume that you have an Active Directory security group called **US Users Group**.
trans-unit.target: These examples assume that you have an Active Directory security group called **US Users Group**.

trans-unit.source: First, provide general information.
trans-unit.target: First, provide general information.

trans-unit.source: Screenshot of the Edit Group area
trans-unit.target: Screenshot of the Edit Group area

trans-unit.source: Under **Membership criteria**, select **US Users Group**, synced with Active Directory, as the security group to use under membership rules.
trans-unit.target: Under **Membership criteria**, select **US Users Group**, synced with Active Directory, as the security group to use under membership rules.

trans-unit.source: Screenshot of the Edit Group dialog box
trans-unit.target: Screenshot of the Edit Group dialog box

trans-unit.source: Review your entries, and then choose **Finish** to create the group.
trans-unit.target: Review your entries, and then choose **Finish** to create the group.

trans-unit.source: Screenshot of the Edit Group dialog box
trans-unit.target: Screenshot of the Edit Group dialog box

trans-unit.source: In our example, we’ve also created a group called **MEA**, for the Middle East and Asia.
trans-unit.target: In our example, we’ve also created a group called **MEA**, for the Middle East and Asia.

trans-unit.source: If group membership is not populated based on security group membership, make sure that you have assigned Intune licenses to group members.
trans-unit.target: If group membership is not populated based on security group membership, make sure that you have assigned Intune licenses to group members.

trans-unit.source: Groups for specific hardware
trans-unit.target: Groups for specific hardware

trans-unit.source: If your organization requires policies that apply to specific hardware types, you can create groups based on this requirement.
trans-unit.target: If your organization requires policies that apply to specific hardware types, you can create groups based on this requirement.

trans-unit.source: You can base the policies on specific groups that you have already created in your on-premises instance of Active Directory, and then sync them with Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: You can base the policies on specific groups that you have already created in your on-premises instance of Active Directory, and then sync them with Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: You also can create groups directly in Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: You also can create groups directly in Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we use **US Users Group** as the parent group for the **Laptop Users** group.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we use **US Users Group** as the parent group for the **Laptop Users** group.

trans-unit.source: Select Security Group dialog box
trans-unit.target: Select Security Group dialog box

trans-unit.source: At this point, your group's hierarchy should look similar to the next screenshot.
trans-unit.target: At this point, your group's hierarchy should look similar to the next screenshot.

trans-unit.source: You can see that there are now members in the Intune group **Laptop Users**.
trans-unit.target: You can see that there are now members in the Intune group **Laptop Users**.

trans-unit.source: Any policies applied to this group will be applied to BYOD laptop users from the U.S. region.
trans-unit.target: Any policies applied to this group will be applied to BYOD laptop users from the U.S. region.

trans-unit.source: Display of Laptop Users group
trans-unit.target: Display of Laptop Users group

trans-unit.source: Groups for specific operating systems
trans-unit.target: Groups for specific operating systems

trans-unit.source: If your organization requires policies that apply to specific operating systems like Android, iOS, or Windows, you can create groups based on this requirement.
trans-unit.target: If your organization requires policies that apply to specific operating systems like Android, iOS, or Windows, you can create groups based on this requirement.

trans-unit.source: As in earlier examples, you can base them on OS-specific groups that you have already created in your on-premises instance of Active Directory, and sync them with Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: As in earlier examples, you can base them on OS-specific groups that you have already created in your on-premises instance of Active Directory, and sync them with Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: You also can create them directly in your instance of Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: You also can create them directly in your instance of Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: By using the same method from earlier examples, you can create groups based on users <!--devices?--> who use specific operating system platforms.
trans-unit.target: By using the same method from earlier examples, you can create groups based on users <!--devices?--> who use specific operating system platforms.

trans-unit.source: If you have users who use multiple mobile platforms or operating systems and you do not have an automated way to categorize users as Android users, iOS users, or Windows users, consider applying policies at the device level.
trans-unit.target: If you have users who use multiple mobile platforms or operating systems and you do not have an automated way to categorize users as Android users, iOS users, or Windows users, consider applying policies at the device level.

trans-unit.source: This will give you more flexibility to apply policies that are specific to an operating system.
trans-unit.target: This will give you more flexibility to apply policies that are specific to an operating system.

trans-unit.source: You cannot provision groups dynamically based on the operating system of the device.
trans-unit.target: You cannot provision groups dynamically based on the operating system of the device.

trans-unit.source: Instead, do this by using Active Directory or Azure Active Directory security groups.
trans-unit.target: Instead, do this by using Active Directory or Azure Active Directory security groups.

trans-unit.source: Laptop users group
trans-unit.target: Laptop users group

trans-unit.source: After all of your user groups are populated based on your organizational requirements, your group hierarchy should look something like this:
trans-unit.target: After all of your user groups are populated based on your organizational requirements, your group hierarchy should look something like this:

trans-unit.source: Group hierarchy view
trans-unit.target: Group hierarchy view

trans-unit.source: You can use this hierarchy to apply the organization's policies.
trans-unit.target: You can use this hierarchy to apply the organization's policies.

trans-unit.source: Device groups
trans-unit.target: Device groups

trans-unit.source: You also can create similar groups for devices as shown here, starting with a broad group that includes all employee-owned devices, for the BYOD scenario.
trans-unit.target: You also can create similar groups for devices as shown here, starting with a broad group that includes all employee-owned devices, for the BYOD scenario.

trans-unit.source: Create Group dialog box
trans-unit.target: Create Group dialog box

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you select **All devices (computers and mobile)** so that the group will include all BYO devices:
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you select **All devices (computers and mobile)** so that the group will include all BYO devices:

trans-unit.source: Define membership criteria page
trans-unit.target: Define membership criteria page

trans-unit.source: Review your entries, and then choose **Finish** to create the BYOD group.
trans-unit.target: Review your entries, and then choose **Finish** to create the BYOD group.

trans-unit.source: Create Group dialog box
trans-unit.target: Create Group dialog box

trans-unit.source: Continue to create device groups until you have a device group hierarchy that is similar to the user group hierarchy.
trans-unit.target: Continue to create device groups until you have a device group hierarchy that is similar to the user group hierarchy.

trans-unit.source: Your group node in the Intune console will look similar to this:
trans-unit.target: Your group node in the Intune console will look similar to this:

trans-unit.source: Intune groups hierarchy view
trans-unit.target: Intune groups hierarchy view

trans-unit.source: Group hierarchies and naming conventions
trans-unit.target: Group hierarchies and naming conventions

trans-unit.source: To make policy management easier, we recommend that you name each policy according to the purpose, platform, and scope to which you apply it.
trans-unit.target: To make policy management easier, we recommend that you name each policy according to the purpose, platform, and scope to which you apply it.

trans-unit.source: Use a naming standard that follows the group structure that you created when you prepared to apply your policies.
trans-unit.target: Use a naming standard that follows the group structure that you created when you prepared to apply your policies.

trans-unit.source: For instance, for an Android policy that applies to all corporate, Android, mobile devices at the U.S. regional level, you might name the policy **CO_US_Mob_Android_General**.
trans-unit.target: For instance, for an Android policy that applies to all corporate, Android, mobile devices at the U.S. regional level, you might name the policy **CO_US_Mob_Android_General**.

trans-unit.source: Create policy for Android
trans-unit.target: Create policy for Android

trans-unit.source: When you name your policies this way, you can quickly identify policies and their intended use and scope in the **Policies** node, like this:
trans-unit.target: When you name your policies this way, you can quickly identify policies and their intended use and scope in the **Policies** node, like this:

trans-unit.source: Intune policy list
trans-unit.target: Intune policy list
